description: Sample credential structures for the zk-identity verification system

field_descriptions.dateOfBirth: Unix timestamp (seconds since epoch) of the user's date of birth
field_descriptions.citizenshipEncoded: Citizenship encoded as a field element (BigInt)
field_descriptions.userPubkey: User's public key as a field element (used to bind credentials)
field_descriptions.nonce: Random nonce to ensure credential uniqueness and prevent replay attacks

issuerPubkey.x: Issuer's public key X coordinate (elliptic curve point)
issuerPubkey.y: Issuer's public key Y coordinate (elliptic curve point)

proof.a: Groth16 proof component a (G1 point, 2 field elements)
proof.b: Groth16 proof component b (G2 point, 2x2 field elements)
proof.c: Groth16 proof component c (G1 point, 2 field elements)

publicSignals: current_date: Current date as Unix timestamp
required_citizenship: Required citizenship encoded as field element
issuer_a_pubkey_x: Issuer A public key X coordinate
issuer_a_pubkey_y: Issuer A public key Y coordinate
issuer_b_pubkey_x: Issuer B public key X coordinate
issuer_b_pubkey_y: Issuer B public key Y coordinate

notes.encoding: All numeric values are represented as strings to avoid precision loss in JSON
notes.field_elements: Field elements are in the prime field F_p where p is the circuit's prime modulus
notes.timestamps: Timestamps are in milliseconds (JavaScript) or seconds (Unix) depending on context
notes.security: These are example values only. In production, use cryptographically secure random values.
